awd_titl_txt: High Performance Energy Storage Electrodes through Oxide Electrodeposition in Carbon Nanotube Fabric Scaffolds
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports research to investigate the manufacturing of advanced electrochemical energy storage electrodes, furthering both science and engineering and thereby enhancing national prosperity and security. There is increased demand for electrochemical energy storage systems that can provide both high power and high energy densities for applications ranging from portable electronics to electric vehicles. This type of performance is difficult to achieve with electrodes made via slurry-casting, by far the most common manufacturing process. Nanostructured electrode architectures can achieve high power and high energy densities, as has been widely discussed in the scientific literature. However, these nanostructured electrodes usually require many complex processing steps with unknown reproducibility and scalability. This research project studies manufacturing design principles for the electrodeposition of transition metal oxides onto aligned carbon nanotube fabrics. This new process enables the controllable and scalable fabrication of high-performance nanostructured energy storage electrodes. The fundamental understanding developed as part of this research is applicable to a wide range of oxide-based and electrodeposited energy storage materials, thus benefitting the U.S. economy and society. In addition to training of graduate students, the education plan of the project includes the development of a 'Materials Manufacturing Design Principles' course module, instructions for which will be shared on publicly-accessible websites. 

The overarching goal of this research is to develop and understand the manufacturing design principles that yield nanostructured aligned carbon nanotube fabric and transition metal oxide electrochemical energy storage electrodes with high power and high energy densities. Achieving this goal overcomes the technical barriers that are typically faced in the scale-up of nanostructured electrodes and provides a transformative route for energy storage processing with the potential for far-reaching industrial impact. Manufacturing design principles are applied to the nanomaterial synthesis and assembly, specifically, reducing the number of materials and processing steps for predictable assembly, utilizing surface functionalization to enable material self-location and self-adhesion, and enabling modularity. The researchers utilize advanced materials characterization techniques to determine the relationships between processing and electrode architecture, composition, and electrochemical performance. Finite-element modeling is utilized to correlate the electrode microstructure, such as oxide grain size or thickness, with the extent of electrochemical intercalation. The fundamental understanding from this research leads to predictive control over nanostructured energy storage architectures with both high power and high energy densities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to develop and understand the nanomanufacturing design principles that will yield carbon - transition metal oxide composite electrodes with high power and high energy densities for electrochemical energy storage applications. This work led to outcomes in electrode synthesis, fabrication, and modeling, as detailed below:

(1) A route toward porous electrodes of MoO3 on CNT foam scaffolds: We found a route towards deterministic energy storage electrode design where the placement of each component is intentional, not random as in slurry-based electrodes (the current industry standard). To do this, we utilized CNT foam fabrics as conductive 3D scaffolds onto which we electrodeposited a model intercalation-type material, MoO3. Electrodeposition from an aqueous solution is a scalable manufacturing route that provides control over the oxide nucleation and growth. We found the parameters that lead to homogeneous electrodeposition of the MoO3, with a scalable route for high mass loading, and reproducibility. We controlled the oxide mass loading and thickness as well as varied the CNT foam thickness. We developed a route to anneal and calender the electrodes to improve adhesion, capacity, and thickness. This method led to reproducible synthesis of 3D CNT fabric/ MoO3 electrodes with active mass loading > 10 mg/cm2, which is what is necessary for most portable electronics applications.

(2)  Developed a mesoscale modeling framework to understand the relationship between the electrode physical descriptors and effective properties: We investigated the relationship between an electrode’s physical descriptors and its effective properties such as tortuosity, electronic conductivity, and interfacial area to develop deterministic electrode architectures. We utilized supervised machine learning models for accurate estimation of effective properties and analysis of the physical phenomenon in electrodes. Ultimately this analysis also paves the way to automate the process of empirical relation development truly from observations (i.e., data samples) through a trained supervised machine learning model.

(3) Mechanistic understanding of low-temperature LiCoO2 deposition on carbon scaffolds: We obtained mechanistic understanding of the factors that determine the deposited LiCoO2 structure and microstructure, which in turn affect the electrode architecture electrochemical behavior. We found that our method results in LiCoO2 formed through either a dissolution/re-precipitation or ion exchange mechanism, depending on the processing conditions. Dissolution / re-precipitation is active at higher temperatures and pressures and on low surface area carbon scaffolds. This mechanism results in the deposition of nanoscale spherical particles of LiCoO2 on the scaffold.  Ion exchange is active at lower temperatures and pressures and on higher surface area carbon scaffolds. This topotactic mechanism results in little change between the precursor (cobalt hydroxide) and the LiCoO2 deposit, and the microstructure consists of micron-scale platelets on the scaffolds. In both mechanisms, deposition can take place on the surface on the scaffolds. The two morphologies appear to give two competing behaviors electrochemically: whereas the dissolution/re-precipitation process results in smaller particles they are not well-adhered to the carbon scaffold. In the case of the ion exchange, the microstructure is larger but the particles are well adhered to the scaffold.  

(4) Kinetic behavior, modeling, and design of porous ion insertion electrode materials: We worked to understand the cyclic voltammetry behavior of porous insertion electrodes using LiCoO2 as the model material. In particular, we were interested in understanding the relationship between peak current and scan rate and used experiments and multi-physics modeling to determine the influence of electrode parameters such as thickness and mass loading on the resulting cyclic voltammetry response.

The broader impacts goals of the proposed research are to reimagine the way materials are brought together for electrode architectures via a scalable manufacturing process, and to develop education activities around energy storage material and device manufacturing. The project provided training in energy storage materials and devices for six graduate student researchers and four undergraduate student researchers, who learned to perform research and disseminate their results via presntations and scientific publications.


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Veronica Augustyn
